comments:
It seems that bug I entered 49281, which was marked as a duplicate of fixed
47927 is still in there in some other form. So, I have fill another bug report
for the same issue.

Once I install JCOP 3.0 tools from
http://www.zurich.ibm.com/jcop/products/tools3.html using update manger, Eclipse
3.0 M6 (N20040121) crash on start with NPE exception. If I manually delete
JCOP features and plugins it again works fine.

Here is the log file:

(this is *not* the same issue as in bug 49281)

In builds < n20040123, PluginDescriptor#getLabel could return null (wrong) if a
bundle's manifest did not contain a "Bundle-Name" entry. This has been fixed
(PluginDescriptor rev. 1.14). 

What is not clear is how the bundle manifest for the plug-in does not contain
that entry (since it should have been automatically generated from the plugin
manifest name attribute, which is required).

Could the original poster comment on whether or not they have a manifest.mf in 
their plugin?  If not, can you attach the plugin.xml so we can see why the 
generated manifest is invalid.

It's not my plugin. but IBM product which can be installed from the Eclipse
update web site at http://www.zurich.ibm.com/jcop/download/eclipse

If you can advice where to look at, I can check for manifests, etc.

Thank you.

thanks for the pointer.  I suspect that it does not have a manifest.  We can 
look at the plugin.xml and see what is happening.

I tried with I200402101200 and it works. 
This is the result of a fix that has been introduced since M6.

What happened is that every jar from an update site contains a manifest.mf 
generated by the jar utility. However this manifest does not have the proper 
OSGi headers and therefore was causing the exception you saw.

The fix we introduced check for some well-known headers in the manifest and if 
it does not contains it, a manifest is generated from plugin.xml.
